And if you do something of your own accord, you do it without prompting from someone else. As a verb, [31maccord[0m means to be in harmony or agreement, or to allow. Perhaps your enhanced vocabulary will accord you, or allow you, a better understanding of language.

The exact meaning of this formal verb varies in intensity depending generally on who is being corrected. If a child or subordinate is being admonished, it means "scold" or "rebuke" whereas if someone admonishes a person with equal standing, [31mwarn[0m or [31madvise[0m are closer synonyms.

The strength and tone of an admonition determine whether it's a gentle, polite suggestion or more of a stern warning. In Scotland, an [31madmonition[0m is an official legal term that means a verbal punishment for someone who's been found guilty but set free.

allege.colored_long: If you ever watch news programs, you often hear the verb [31mallege[0m. A reporter might say that detectives allege that a certain person, who is now being held without bail, set a fire. This can be confusing: If the person is in jail, then he or she must have set that fire, right? In reality, the person is a suspect, awaiting trial. In our country, people are assumed innocent until proven guilty in a court of law. That's why we used [31mallege[0m until we know for sure.

If done to a person, it excommunicated them, meaning they could no longer partake in the church's sacraments (with presumably pretty poor consequences for the soul.) That's a lot worse than kryptonite.

barter.colored_long: Before money was invented, people traded goods and services in order to acquire the things they needed. An individual might trade, for example, a cow in exchange for help building a shed, or a dozen eggs in exchange for several yards of cloth. To this day people continue to barter for goods and services although this method of commerce is no longer widespread. The verb [31mbarter[0m has survived into modern times to refer to making a transaction that involves the exchange of goods or services rather than money.

bombast.colored_long: Originally, [31mbombast[0m was cotton padding used to stuff or pad things like seat cushions. The meaning was extended to include padded and overstuffed speaking or writing, especially speech that's pretentious and showy. Other words with [31mbombast[0m at their roots include the adjective [31mbombastic[0m and the adverb [31mbombastically[0m. For all your coach's bluster and bombast, he's a pretty nice guy â€” too bad his overblown rhetoric turns people off before they get to know him.
bombast.colored_short: [31mBombast[0m is a noun meaning pretentious or boastful talk. If your football coach is known for his [31mbombast[0m, he probably gives a pompous speech before each game about the greatness of the team and, of course, his coaching.
bombast.long: Originally, bombast was cotton padding used to stuff or pad things like seat cushions. cacophony.colored_long: A [31mcacophony[0m is a jarring, discordant mix of sounds that have no business being played together. When the orchestra tunes up before a show, it sounds like a cacophony because each musician is playing a completely different tune, at different times, and at different volumes. Once the show begins, that cacophony had better turn into a melody, or audiences will demand a refund. This allegedly occurred during the first time Igor Stravinsky's score for the ballet "The Rite of Spring" was performed because its difficult composition and discordant tone was shocking.
cacophony.colored_short: A [31mcacophony[0m is a mishmash of unpleasant sounds, often at loud volume. It's what you'd hear if you gave instruments to a group of four-year-olds and asked them to play one of Beethoven's symphonies.

conflagration.colored_long: That tiny campfire that somehow turned into a raging forest inferno? You could call that intense, uncontrolled blaze a conflagration. Mrs. O'Leary's cow knew a thing or two about conflagrations: It was that unknowing animal that kicked over a kerosene lamp in the night, setting the O'Leary's barn on fire and sending four square miles of the Windy City into that blistering conflagration known as the Great Chicago Fire of 1871.

conflated.colored_long: The verb [31mconflate[0m comes to us from the Latin word [31mconflare[0m, which literally means "to blow together." So think of using this word when you want to talk about two things getting thrown together and combined. Things that have been conflated often seem mixed up or confused, as when you conflate two different ideas, taking parts of one and parts of another to build your own Frankenstein version of things.

confound.colored_long: The verb [31mconfound[0m means both "to mistake" and "to confuse." If you decide to treat yourself to a delicious dessert, you might find yourself confounded by the overwhelming number of choices. If you end up ordering the chocolate cake but the waiter brings you chocolate mousse, the waiter has somehow confounded those two options. Another meaning you may come across in literature is "to damn," as in "[31mConfound[0m it! You are the most exasperating person on the planet."
confound.colored_short: If you have an identical twin, you've probably tried dressing alike so that people [31mconfound[0m you with, or mistake you for, one another. You've also probably learned that, unfortunately, this trick doesn’t work on your mom.

connoisseur.colored_long: A connoisseur is an authority in his field, someone who has expert knowledge and training, especially in the arts. A [31mconnoisseur[0m may also be someone with an extremely developed sense of taste, like the connoisseur who can identify rare wine by a flavor others can't even detect. Then again, some people call themselves connoisseurs of just about anything they like — pizza, old vinyl albums, even cartoons — because they know so much about it.
connoisseur.colored_short: A [31mconnoisseur[0m is a person who, through study and interest, has a fine appreciation for something, like the [31mconnoisseur[0m who can identify the clarinet player on a jazz recording by the sound of his inhalations alone.

contentious.colored_long: Some issues — like abortion, the death penalty, and gun control — are very controversial. debilitate.colored_long: The verb [31mdebilitate[0m traces back to the Latin word [31mdebilis[0m, meaning “lame, disabled, crippled.” It’s often used to describe what disability or illness does to a person's health, but it can describe anything that has been weakened, like the sense of community that is slowly debilitated by people working longer hours and the lack of sidewalks that in many towns make it harder to walk around and meet the neighbors.

Because French was spoken mostly by the ruling class, many of the loan words are formal. [31mDecry[0m comes from the Old French [31mdescrier,[0m to cry out or announce. When you [31mdecry[0m something, you simultaneously condemn it and discredit it, a formal act.

defiance.colored_long: We owe this lovely descriptive term to the French — specifically to the Old French word [31mdefier[0m, which means to defy. (Don't mix it up with [31mdeify[0m; that means to make someone or something into a god.) If you've ever studied Latin, you'll spot the [31mfi[0m from [31mfidare[0m "to trust" that inspired the Marines' "semper fi" motto and the popular moniker for pooches––"Fido." Combining [31mfi[0m with [31mde-[0m negates it. So an act of defiance is essentially an act of not trusting.
defiance.colored_short: Stand up when the powers that be order you to sit down, and you've given a fine example of [31mdefiance[0m. It happens when someone or a group of someones openly flouts or challenges authority.

deflect.colored_long: In a cartoon, a mouse might ask an approaching cat, "Hey, what's that up in the sky?" When the cat looks up, the mouse runs away, successful in his attempt to deflect the cat's attention. When you deflect, you throw someone or something off course, often by using a distraction. Another way to deflect something — such as criticism — is to blame someone else. Eventually the truth, like the cat who quickly sees there's nothing unusual up in the sky, catches up with those who deflect.
deflect.colored_short: The verb [31mdeflect[0m describes blocking something or changing its course. Hockey goalies [31mdeflect[0m the flying puck with their sticks or blockers, making it travel in a different direction, preferably to a teammate's stick.

The source of [31mdeft[0m is the Old English [31mgedÃ¦fte[0m, "mild or gentle," which became [31mdeft[0m in Middle English along with its meaning of "apt, skillful, or adept."

demagogue.colored_long: Though the Greek root for [31mdemagogue[0m literally means "a leader of the people," the word has for centuries had a negative connotation: it actually means a leader who has manipulated the emotions and prejudices of the rabble. The reason for the negative connotation is that in ancient Athens, "the people" were considered to be an uncivilized mob. Two of the most famous historical demagogues are said to be Adolf Hitler and Josef Stalin.
demagogue.colored_short: A [31mdemagogue[0m is someone who becomes a leader largely because of skills as a speaker or who appeals to emotions and prejudices.

diffidence.colored_long: The noun [31mdiffidence[0m comes from the Latin word [31mdiffidere[0m, meaning "to mistrust" or "to lack confidence." Diffidence is often mistaken for snootiness because people don't understand that the diffident person is shy and lacking in confidence. "They asked him to be the team leader, but he expressed diffidence, saying that he didn't think he had enough time to do the job justice, nor did he think he had enough experience."

discernment.colored_long: The noun [31mdiscernment[0m describes a wise way of judging between things, or a particularly perceptive way of seeing things. If you can understand something that's somewhat hidden or obscure — if you figure out the themes of a confusing movie, for example — you're using discernment. It comes from the Latin word [31mdiscernere[0m, meaning "separate." Discernment separates what's important or true from what's not.

discord.colored_long: [31mDiscord[0m can be broken down into the prefix [31mdis[0m, meaning "different," and [31mcord[0m, which stems from an old word for "heart." So that leaves us with "different hearts." So if we're talking about music, discord means a lack of harmony — tones that clash so badly your ears bleed. But when there's discord between people, their hearts are in different places — which usually results in more than a few raised voices clashing disharmoniously.

disparage.colored_long: [31mDisparage[0m is a specific way to describe a certain kind of insult, the kind that secures the insulter's place as superior. It often refers to an opinion or criticism lobbed in print or via word of mouth, not necessarily an act done to someone's face. If someone or something is being disparaged, you will often find a competing interest in the wings.

disseminate.colored_long: Think about a teacher distributing a hand out at the beginning of a class. The [31mdis-[0m  of [31mdisseminate[0m and [31mdistribute[0m come from the same Latin prefix which means "apart, in a different direction." But unlike papers distributed in class, information, once spread around in all directions, cannot be pulled back in. Think about false rumors or political smear campaigns and you'll understand that dissemination is usually a one-way process.

eclectic.colored_long: The English word [31meclectic[0m first appeared in the seventeenth century to describe philosophers who did not belong to a particular school of thought, but instead assembled their doctrines by picking and choosing from a variety of philosophical systems. Today, the word can refer to any assemblage of varied parts. You can have an eclectic group of friends (friends from diverse groups), eclectic taste in furniture (a mixture of 18th-century French chairs, Andy Warhol paintings, and Persian rugs), or enjoy eclectic cuisine (fusion cooking that uses ingredients from different national cuisines).
eclectic.colored_short: She listens to hip-hop, Gregorian chant, and folk music from the '60s. He's been seen wearing a handmade tuxedo jacket over a thrift-store flannel shirt. They both have [31meclectic[0m tastes.

endemic.colored_long: Although [31mendemic[0m meaning "prevalent" often describes a plant or disease, it can also refer to something less tangible and more unwanted such as violence or poverty. Many complain of endemic corruption in the local government. Despite its [31m-ic[0m ending, [31mendemic[0m can also be used as a noun to signify a plant or animal that is prevalent in a certain region. If an endemic is brought to another area which it takes over, destroying the local population, it's classified as an invasive species.

A popular band might epitomize the spirit of the new decade, which means it has all the main characteristics associated with the era's music, like long folksy beards, pretty harmonies, and earnest lyrics. A frustrating situation at work involving careless coworkers might make you say that they epitomize everything that’s wrong with your job.

erratic.colored_long: Like its linguistic relative, [31merror[0m, the adjective [31merratic[0m means "deviating from the norm," or "wrong." It also implies behavior or qualities that are unpredictable or odd. The word comes from the Latin verb [31merrare[0m, or "to wander" off course. In the field of geology, a rock that is [31merratic[0m is unlike others in its environment because it has been transported by glacial activity. Likewise, someone driving a car that veers out of its lane is said to be driving [31merratically[0m.

formidable.colored_long: What's interesting about [31mformidable[0m is that we often tend to use it about things that, while they may scare us, we can't help being pretty impressed by all the same. A formidable opponent is almost by definition a worthy one; a formidable challenge is almost by definition one worth rising to. Not surprisingly, this word is derived from the Latin [31mformidare,[0m "to fear."
formidable.colored_short: What do the national debt, your old gym teacher, and your mother-in-law have in common? They're all [31mformidable[0m — that is, they inspire fear and respect thanks to their size, or special ability, or unusual  qualities. (Or possibly all three in the case of your mother-in-law.)

futility.colored_long: What’s the point?  That’s the question asked by anyone who senses the futility of something.  The futility of war makes soldiers put down their weapons, and your father’s strict rules makes any protest an act of futility.   The root word is the Latin [31mfutilis[0m, which literally means “leaky.”  Imagine pouring lemonade into a cup that has no bottom.  No matter how long you pour, you’ll never get a sip because of that leaky cup.  Ah, the futility!

hedonistic.colored_long: This term — along with the related words [31mhedonist[0m and [31mhedonistic[0m — is derived from the Greek word [31mhedone[0m, "pleasure." The Cyreniacs taught that physical gratification is superior to the mental satisfaction offered by anticipation and remembrance. That's why hedonistic folks revel in pleasure, and demand it in the present tense.

hoodwink.colored_long: An excellent, old-fashioned word is [31mhoodwink[0m, and youâ€™ll be happy you know it when you have to read Victorian novels in which characters are repeatedly hoodwinked. It is an Old English compound which meant "to blindfold" 600 years ago but quickly began to be used figuratively. Think about the expression, to pull the wool over someone's eyes, as having the same image and meaning. Has your big sister ever hoodwinked you into doing her chores for her?

hose.colored_long: A garden hose is useful for watering plants or washing your car, while firefighters use hoses to spray water on fires. A hose is similar to a pipe, being long, narrow, and hollow, with space for liquid to move through it, although a hose is flexible, and a pipe is commonly made of stiff metal or hard plastic. You can use the word as a verb, meaning "to spray with a [31mhose[0m," or as a noun meaning "sheer stockings."
hose.colored_short: A [31mhose[0m is a long plastic or rubber tube that's used for moving a liquid from one place to another. You may use a [31mhose[0m to water your lawn, or to get gas from the pump into your car's tank.  Don't use a [31mhose[0m to ingest liquids; use a glass instead.

idiosyncrasy.colored_long: [31mIdio[0m seems like it means stupid, but really it is Latin for "one's own," as an [31midiosyncrasy[0m is one's own particular, usually odd, behavior. Putting salt in your hot chocolate or needing the light on to sleep or tapping your head while you think are all idiosyncrasies. A machine such as a DVD player has an idiosyncrasy if you have to do something weird to it to make it work like having to bang it on the back left-hand side to stop it from skipping.

immunize.colored_long: Vaccines work by arming your immune system against being infected â€” in other words, they produce immunity, or immunize you. impeach.colored_long: If you impeach a president, you charge him or her with a crime. Congress may vote to impeach a president, but being impeached is only the first step in removing an official from office. [31mImpeach[0m comes from the Latin [31mimpedicare[0m, meaning "catch, entangle." To impeach also means to cast doubt on someone's character.  In a courtroom, a lawyer could impeach the credibility of a witness in order to discredit whatever that person said.
impeach.colored_short: [31mImpeach[0m means to charge someone with doing something wrong, specifically a high government official, such as the U.S. president, a senator, or a federal judge. Fortunately, very few presidents have had the dishonor of being [31mimpeached[0m.

impeccable.colored_long: The adjective [31mimpeccable[0m refers to something or someone without marking or error â€” but it can describe something spotless or clean. The word comes from the Latin [31mimpeccabilis[0m, "to be sinless," which is also an outdated sense in English. You can see how "clean" comes from "sinless." Because of the messy nature of picnic food, it is highly unlikely that you would leave with your clothing still as impeccable as when you arrived, especially if you like lots of mustard and ketchup!

Other synonyms are [31mstupid, vacuous, ridiculous, pointless[0m.

That’s the whole point: you don’t have the words for it yet!

innocuous.colored_long: The adjective [31minnocuous[0m is useful when you're talking about something that doesn't offend or injure anyone. Innocuous remarks or comments are meant kindly, and innocuous germs won't make you sick. An innocuous question is innocently curious, rather than aimed to hurt someone's feelings. The word comes from the Latin roots [31min-[0m, "not," and [31mnocere[0m, "to injure or harm."

inscrutable.colored_long: A good way to think about what [31minscrutable[0m means is to consider cats and dogs. Dogs wear their hearts on their sleeves, shaking when they're afraid and bouncing up and down when they're happy. Dogs are definitely not inscrutable, because you can tell what they're thinking and feeling. On the other hand, cats are very difficult to read. Even longtime cat owners aren't always sure what's going on with their kitty. Cats are very inscrutable animals.

When something is instigated, the outcome tends to be unknown. The plan you instigate might not lead to the desired result.

knotty.colored_long: The adjective [31mknotty[0m is a way to describe something that’s covered in knots. It can be used in a literal sense to refer to wood that is covered in hard, irregular knots — you’ve probably seen these circular, knobby imperfections that sometime appear on wood. The word can also be used figuratively to describe something that is intricate and difficult to solve, such as a knotty political problem involving two warring nations or a knotty legal issue involving complicated constitutional issues.

maverick.colored_long: Samuel A. Maverick owned a lot of cattle, and he let them roam around Texas without a brand, or identification mark, seared into their skins. Samuel was a maverick for going against the common practice of tracking his animals, and his last name became part of the English language as both an adjective and a noun in the 19th century. Someone who acts very independently is a maverick, and individual actions that stand out are maverick, as in "her maverick jumping style on the ice was both wild and delicate."
maverick.colored_short: A [31mmaverick[0m is a rebel, someone who shows a lot of independence. A [31mmaverick[0m on a motorcycle might blaze her own trail, traveling around the country and earning money by performing in rodeos.

melancholy.colored_long: Being melancholy means that you're overcome in sorrow, wrapped up in sorrowful thoughts. The word started off as a noun for deep sadness, from a rather disgusting source. Back in medieval times, people thought that secretions of the body called "humors" determined their feelings, so a depressed person was thought to have too much of the humor known as [31mmelancholy[0m â€” literally "black bile" secreted from the spleen. Fortunately, we no longer think we're ruled by our spleens, and that black bile has been replaced by another color of sorrow: the "blues."

mercenary.colored_long: The word [31mmercenary[0m comes from the Latin [31mmercēnārius,[0m "hireling," which defines someone who will do anything in exchange for money. In history, a mercenary was often a fighter who followed the next paycheck, but in recent decades it's also been used for fighters who pursue a good cause in areas where soldiers are in short supply. A synonym for mercenary is "soldier of fortune," and this phrase sometimes glorifies the mercenary, turning the meaning of "fortune" from "cash" to "luck in battle."
mercenary.colored_short: You might not want to call a [31mmercenary[0m a "hireling" to his face, but a mercenary is, after all, a soldier who gets paid to fight where needed, sometimes taking a heroic stand and other times just wanting payment for fighting.

motley.colored_long: In contemporary usage, [31mmotley[0m can be used in virtually any context as a synonym for mismatched, heterogeneous, or ragtag. But the word was first used to describe multicolored fabric, especially the type of material used in a jester's costume. This distinctive apparel was a sign of the fool's place outside the class system â€” and, in the Elizabethan era, it signified that the jester was beyond the sumptuary laws that determined who could wear what. Thus, the fool had the exceptional ability to speak freely, even to royalty.

nemesis.colored_long: The word [31mnemesis[0m describes a rival who just somehow seems able to get the best of you. [...] can also refer to something that always causes you problems, like public speaking, the nemesis of those who get tongue-tied when nervous.
nemesis.masked_short: Use the word [...] to describe someone or something that always causes you major problems, like the runner on another school's track team who, for years, has been beating your time by a fraction of a second.

Now where would we be without niceties?

Although usually used as a noun, the word [31mnutrient[0m started out in 1650 as an adjective meaning "providing nourishment." obstreperous.colored_long: If you’ve been to a large concert where the band doesn't come on stage for hours, you might have been part of an obstreperous crowd: increasingly impatient, with fights breaking out, things thrown up onto the stage, and demands being shouted, "Give us some music before the night is out!" Some people are kind and gentle with strangers, but around their own family turn obstreperous, shouting "You never loved me!" at their mom when she gives them the smaller of two cookies.
obstreperous.colored_short: [31mObstreperous[0m means boisterous, noisy, aggressive, defiant. You’ve probably seen an [31mobstreperous[0m child in the grocery store, pulling away from her mother, screaming at the top of her lungs.

obstruct.colored_long: [31mObstruct[0m also means to get in the way so that you hide something from view. That fast food tower being built next to your beach house will obstruct your lovely ocean vistas. And that scene gives you a vivid illustration of the Latin roots the word comes from: [31mob-[0m "against," and [31mstruere,[0m "build." You can also [31mobstruct[0m something or someone by putting up a roadblock, literal or figurative: when you park yourself by the exit door, you obstruct everybody's way out.
obstruct.colored_short: When you [31mobstruct[0m something, you block it. If you’re gobbling down your pizza, a chunk of crust you didn’t chew so well might [31mobstruct[0m your airway and you'll choke.

ornate.colored_long: Look at the first four letters of [31mornate[0m, and you'll spot the beginning of its close relative [31mornament[0m. [31mOrnate[0m most often describes how something looks, but it doesn't have to be visual. The prose in Victorian love letters was more ornate than the email messages people send today. The ornate gilded mirrors and enormous chandeliers in the palace at Versailles were the height of fashion in Marie Antoinette's time, but home decor is simpler today. Now, it seems too ornate.
ornate.colored_short: If something is [31mornate[0m — whether it's a ball gown, a set of dishes, or a poem — it seems to be covered in ornaments. It's lavish, flowery, or heavily adorned.

ossify.colored_long: From the literal "to become bony" meaning of [31mossify[0m, we get the more figurative meaning: to become rigid or hardened. Although you and other young people may be willing to effect social changes, many older voters have ossified in their opinions. Convincing these rigid thinkers that these changes are good for the country will be quite the challenge. If your kids sneak food to their rooms, you may find ossified cheese under the beds. Even mice won't touch that!
ossify.colored_short: [31mOssify[0m means to become bony. When a baby is born, some of their "bones" are actually soft cartilage, which allows for growth. As the child grows, these soft areas [31mossify[0m into actual bone. The knee cap, for example, begins to ossify between ages 3 and 6.

pajamas.colored_long: [31mPajamas[0m is always plural — it's got that in common with words like pants, shorts, and trousers. Like these other plural clothing words, pajamas have two legs — they're like a loose, soft, and very comfortable pair of pants. This word started out in 1800 as two: [31mpai jamahs[0m, "loose trousers tied at the waist," worn by Europeans in imitation of traditional Indian Muslim clothing. The Persian root, [31mpaejamah[0m, combines [31mpae[0m, "leg," and [31mjamah[0m, "clothing."
pajamas.colored_short: [31mPajamas[0m are clothes made for sleeping in. When you're not feeling well, there's nothing better than putting on your [31mpajamas[0m, climbing into bed, and having someone bring you a cup of tea.

palliate.colored_long: [31mPalliate[0m is the word to use when you want to make something feel or seem better. [31mPalliate[0m doesn’t mean “cure” or “solve.” Instead, something that palliates relieves the symptoms or consequences of something, without addressing the underlying cause. Your dentist might give you pain-killing drugs to palliate the discomfort caused by an impacted molar, but that molar is still there, waiting to cause more trouble.
palliate.colored_short: When you [31mpalliate[0m something, you try to make something less bad: “City leaders tried to palliate effects of the trash haulers' strike by distributing extra large garbage cans with tight-fitting lids.”

palliative.colored_long: From the French [31mpalliatif[0m, which in turn came from the Middle Latin [31mpalliates[0m, [31mpalliative[0m was first recorded as an adjective in the 1540’s, and then later as a noun in 1724. To [31mpalliate[0m is to alleviate without curing, so it makes sense that a [31mpalliative[0m is the agent for this type of relief. “Life as we find it, is too hard for us: it brings us too many pains, disappointments and impossible tasks,” said the founder of psychoanalysis Sigmund Freud. “In order to bear it, we cannot dispense with [31mpalliative[0m measures…”
palliative.colored_short: That which is [31mpalliative[0m relieves and soothes, but isn’t expected to cure. A heating pack is a commonly employed [31mpalliative[0m for temporarily reducing the pain of strained muscles.

parlor.colored_long: The noun [31mparlor[0m is an old-fashioned one. Still, almost anyone would know what you meant if you invited them to join you in the parlor for tea. These days, a hotel, inn, or historic house is more likely to have a parlor than a private home is. The thirteenth century version, [31mparlur[0m, meant "room in a monastery for holding conversations." The "conversations" part stems from [31mparler[0m, "to speak" in French.
parlor.colored_short: A [31mparlor[0m is a living room or a sitting room, the place in your house with comfortable chairs and sofas. You might also decide to put your giant new TV in the [31mparlor[0m.

parody.colored_long: A parody is a form of humor that spoofs — or satirizes — something using the same form. For example, shows like "Saturday Night Live" and "The Daily Show" parody newscasts by doing fake newscasts that look like the real thing. Comedians and comedy writers love to parody the President. Anything in the public eye could be the object of a parody.

plethora.colored_long: [31mPlethora[0m comes from the Greek for "fullness." Although it was originally used only in old-fashioned medicine to describe the condition of having too much blood, we use it to talk about any excessive supply.  If you run a theater and all the seats are taken, that's a full house. But if the seats are full and people are standing in the aisles, you have a plethora of patrons. The stress is on the first syllable: PLETH-uh-ruh.

preachy.colored_long: When you're preachy, you feel morally superior to other people and you're not afraid to talk about what you think they should do. A preachy neighbor might complain about how rude the kids on his block are and suggest that their parents should teach them some manners. A preachy children's book might have a patronizing message about always saying "please" and "thank you." [31mPreachy[0m is an informal adjective that dates from the nineteenth century.

precautionary.colored_long: If you do it beforehand to protect someone or something, it's precautionary. You may be sure you don't have a concussion after wiping out on your bike, but getting checked out at the emergency room would be a smart, precautionary move anyway. Putting on your helmet before you raced your bike down that hill was also precautionary. The Late Latin source of [31mprecautionary[0m is [31mpraecautionem[0m, "a safeguarding," from the Latin [31mpraecavere[0m, "to guard against beforehand."
precautionary.colored_short: Anything that might prevent something unpleasant or dangerous from happening is [31mprecautionary[0m. If you're babysitting your neighbor's three year old triplets, you might want to hide every fragile thing in your house as a [31mprecautionary[0m measure first.

reprieve.colored_long: For some, a night at the opera is a night of punishing boredom during which the only reprieve is the intermission. For others, it's baseball that feels like torture. The seventh-inning stretch is the only reprieve from a night of endless waiting. Often, you'll hear [31mreprieve[0m used when a court or governor decides not to execute a prisoner. That prisoner is given a reprieve and will be allowed to live. He probably won't get a reprieve from prison, though, unless he's found innocent.
reprieve.colored_short: A [31mreprieve[0m is a break in or cancellation of a painful or otherwise lousy situation. If you're being tortured, a [31mreprieve[0m is a break from whatever's tormenting you.

restive.colored_long: It's not only people who can be [31mrestive[0m: the world suffers from much turmoil, and there are restive areas, where people are unhappy or oppressed and desperate for change. It's that need for change and movement that makes someone restive or eager to move, frustrated at being stuck in one place. This sense of being stuck is obvious in the history of the word, which was first used in the 15th century. It evolved from the Anglo-French adjective [31mrestif[0m, which meant "refusing to move ahead." Picture a restive horse, refusing to take a jump.
restive.colored_short: To be [31mrestive[0m is to be impatient or on edge — it's an edgy state. When you feel like your skin is too tight and your nerves are ready to snap, when you feel ready to explode, you are [31mrestive[0m.

retroactive.colored_long: The Latin word [31mretroagere[0m, an ancestor of the adjective [31mretroactive[0m, means "drive or turn back," and goes  along with the meaning of the word. Sometimes governments pass rulings that are set as if they were in effect before the ruling was even made, and that means they are retroactive. On the bright side, you might be awarded a salary raise that is retroactive, meaning you'll get paid more for work you did in the past. And, [31mretroactive[0m fads in clothing keep vintage clothing stores in business.
retroactive.colored_short: The adjective [31mretroactive[0m refers to something happening now that affects the past. For example, a [31mretroactive[0m tax is one that is passed at one time, but payable back to a time before the tax was passed.

If a planet like Mercury is in retrograde, that means it appears to be moving backwards. [31mRetrograde[0m can also describe something that's going from better to worse. The farm's retrograde practice of spraying their crops with harsher and harsher pesticides is causing our health to suffer.

steadfast.colored_long: The word [31msteadfast[0m traces back to the Old English word [31mstedefæst[0m, a combination of [31mstede[0m, meaning "place," and [31mfæst[0m, meaning "firmly fixed." Picture a steadfast person standing firmly in place, not wavering or budging an inch, and you’ll have a good sense of what this word means. Someone can be steadfast in a belief, an effort, a plan, or even a refusal. Whatever it is, it means that the person will calmly hold firm to the chosen position and follow through with determination.

The metaphoric sense of [31mstifle[0m didn’t develop until well after the word was first recorded as a verb: "I can always tell — but never let on for fear of damaging his ego — that my boyfriend attempts to [31mstifle[0m tears during sappy parts of movies; his eyes well up at the corners and he’ll sniffle uncontrollably, claiming allergies."

The phrase "all and [31msundry[0m" refers collectively to a group of people, as in, "I invited [31mall and sundry[0m of my relatives to my tea party."

taxing.colored_long: Things that are taxing wear you out, either physically or mentally (or both). You may think of physical jobs like construction work as the most taxing kind of employment, until you realize how emotionally taxing it would be to care for sick patients as a nurse, or how mentally taxing you might find working as an accountant. This adjective comes from the verb [31mtax[0m, which means "to put a strain on."

So toad-eater, later shortened to toady, came to mean a person who would do anything to please his boss.

vacillate.colored_long: Something that [31mvacillates[0m sways or fluctuates, often quite unsteadily. So use this verb to describe the staggering motions of a person who has had too much to drink, as well as the opinions of someone who can’t make up her mind. Synonyms include [31mvibrate[0m, [31mhesitate[0m, and [31mwaver[0m. A wise Ethiopian proverb advises, "Do not vacillate or you will be left in between doing something, having something, and being nothing.”
vacillate.colored_short: [31mVacillate[0m means to waver back and forth, unable to decide. You might [31mvacillate[0m between ordering waffles and pancakes at your favorite diner — it’s hard to pick just one when both are so tasty!

vacuity.colored_long: This abstract noun is derived from the adjective [31mvacuous[0m, which means "like or of a vacuum." [31mVacuity[0m is rarely used to refer to actual vacuums; it is instead used to disparage arguments, morals, and undertakings that lack proper substance. These transferred meanings are more common for the adjective as well. Use them both sparingly: they are nearly always a marker that you have your judgment hat on!

valve.colored_long: The simplest type of valve has a hinged flap allowing liquid to flow one direction, but blocking it from going the other way. This is called a "check valve." Anatomical valves  — systems in your body that allow a flow of fluid, like the aortic valve near your heart  — are structured very much the same way. The shells of mollusks like oysters and clams are also called [31mvalves[0m. The word's earliest meaning was "one half of a folding door."

Stealing someone's significant other is venomous. Anytime someone is being destructive on purpose, it's venomous. vernal.colored_long: The word [31mvernal[0m entered English in the sixteenth century, tracing all the way back to the Latin word [31mver[0m, meaning spring. Use the adjective [31mvernal[0m to describe something that occurs in springtime or is related to springtime. You might be familiar with the vernal equinox, which indicates the beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere. The word [31mvernal[0m can also be used more broadly to describe something youthful or fresh — springlike.

vignette.colored_long: Over the centuries a vignette has taken on different forms. Originally it was one of those small sketches you find in the front of old books, often with decorative bands of ivy around its edges (the word comes from the French [31mvigne[0m for vineyard). When cinema came along, a vignette became a quick portrait in film of a character. Some films, like Robert Altman's [31mShort Cuts,[0m are essentially just a compilation of individual vignettes.
vignette.colored_short: A [31mvignette[0m is a brief but powerful scene. A good [31mvignette[0m leaves you wanting more.

virtuosity.colored_long: Lots of people have talents, but only a select few, called virtuosos, have the superior quality of virtuosity. A piano virtuoso, for example, is able to play and improvise at the highest level possible. People can also display virtuosity in speaking, in writing computer code, in cooking, or in other skills. In the late fifteenth century, [31mvirtuosity[0m specifically meant "manly qualities," from the Latin root [31mvirtutem[0m, "manliness, valor, or excellence."

In the late fifteenth century, [...] specifically meant "manly qualities," from the Latin root [...], "manliness, valor, or excellence."

viscid.colored_long: The word [31mviscid[0m is from the Latin word [31mviscum[0m, or birdlime. Birdlime is a sticky substance made from sap and is smeared on branches. Small birds land on the branches and are trapped, allowing someone to easily catch them. The word [31mviscous[0m comes from the same root and has a similar meaning â€” think of lava and how it moves slowly and thickly down a mountain.
viscid.colored_short: The adjective [31mviscid[0m is used to describe something that is sticky or a thick, slow-moving liquid. If you bake bread and you get flour all over your counters, clean it up carefully because adding water can turn the flour into a [31mviscid[0m paste, and then you'll really have a mess!

viscid.short: The adjective viscid is used to describe something that is sticky or a thick, slow-moving liquid. If you bake bread and you get flour all over your counters, clean it up carefully because adding water can turn the flour into a viscid paste, and then you'll really have a mess!

viscous.colored_long: Not quite a solid and not quite a liquid, scientists like to say that viscous things don't flow very easily. They glop and slug around slowly, sticking to whatever they come in contact with. Think of making a batch of Rice Krispie treats: One minute the marshmallows are solid little rounds; the next minute they're melted into a web of sticky white goo that's somehow attached itself to the Rice Krispies, the spoon, the countertops, your nose, the front door, and the dog.
viscous.colored_short: [31mViscous[0m means sticky, gluey and syrupy. So if something is [31mviscous[0m, you usually don't want to stick your fingers in it — that goes for boogers and maple syrup alike.

vociferous.colored_long: [31mVociferous[0m is from the Latin [31mvociferari[0m meaning "to shout, yell." If you break it down to the first part, take [31mvox[0m meaning "voice" and add it to [31mferre[0m meaning "to carry," then [31mvociferous[0m describes voices that carry; you can hear a [31mvociferous[0m person from across the room at a dance party. [31mVociferous[0m isn't just loud, but annoying, too, like when the [31mvociferous[0m fans of the opposing team chant insults in unison. Try yanking a cookie out of a little kid's hand if you want to hear a [31mvociferous[0m reaction.

volition.colored_long: [31mVolition[0m comes from Latin and French roots meaning "wish" or "will." Legal speech and writing often include the word [31mvolition,[0m as a way to affirm that a person involved in a crime acted "on their own volition," or consented to be part of the crime. Maybe criminals don't wish to go to jail, but their acts often show their volition to break the law.
volition.colored_short: Doing something willingly or voluntarily is doing it of your own [31mvolition[0m. You might not always enjoy the books your teacher assigns, but you love the historical novels you pick up of your own [31mvolition[0m.

wardrobe.colored_long: From the words [31mwarder[0m, meaning “to protect”, and [31mrobe[0m, meaning a “piece of clothing,” [31mwardrobe[0m originally meant an entire room where a person's clothing was stored. Nowadays, most people don’t have an entire room for their clothes, so the word [31mwardrobe[0m has downsized to just a large cabinet, or the clothing itself. A wardrobe can also be the costumes (or the costume department) of a theater company or  movie.

winnow.colored_long: To winnow is to use air to “separate the wheat from the chaff" — literally or figuratively. If a coach winnows down the top NBA draft picks to his number one choice, then he'll focus his negotiations on that player. Chances are, if you encounter the word [31mwinnow[0m on a given day, it is probably not in the literal context of grain.
winnow.colored_short: To [31mwinnow[0m is to blow something away until you are left with what you want, like grain from chaff. If you only want your favorite people to attend your party, you will need to [31mwinnow[0m down the guest list from 300 to 30.

wobble.colored_long: A cafe table might wobble annoyingly until you prop up one leg with folded paper. And, when you first step off an amusement park ride, your legs might wobble for a while. Your voice can wobble too, or tremble, especially when you're upset or nervous. People wobble figuratively too: "When politicians [31mwobble[0m on important issues, it's hard to trust them."
wobble.colored_short: When things [31mwobble[0m, they teeter or rock unsteadily back and forth. A brand new bike rider is bound to [31mwobble[0m a little bit when she's pedaling down the street.
